awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Determining the Effect of Ammonium on Algae and their Physiology in the Waters of the Hangzhou and Taihu Regions of China
awd_abstract_narration:
China?s marine and freshwaters are among the most nitrogen polluted in the world.  Nitrogen pollution has been linked with severe water quality impairment, ranging from nuisance and toxic algal blooms, oxygen depletion, loss of fisheries, and changes in biodiversity.  Although the effect of total nutrient loading has been well explored in terms of promoting the growth of algae (algal blooms), the effects of changing nitrogen forms and proportions on algal community composition and productivity are poorly understood in systems experiencing prolonged nutrient loading.  In this study, it is hypothesized that nitrogen in the form of ammonium will favor the development of harmful algal blooms, including cyanobacteria and will reduce primary production, compared to when nitrogen in the form of nitrate is available. This project will involve a series of experiments on natural waters collected from the Hangzhou and Taihu regions of China to assess the physiological response of algae to the addition of changing nitrogen forms. This research involves collaboration with Dr. Mengmeng Tong, well known for her expertise in toxic algal blooms, at Zhejiang University, Ocean College. 

Eutrophication observed in China is of particular concern, considering nutrient loads are rising and relative nitrogen (N) forms reaching aquatic ecosystems are changing, resulting in increasing reduced (e.g. NH4+) compared to oxidized forms of N (NO3-).  Not all algae have the same response to nutrient enrichments, and some algae have preferences for different nutrient forms. Natural samples will be variably enriched with NH4+ and NO3- and will be incubated under natural light and temperature conditions for several days during which phytoplankton community composition, biomass accumulation, and productivity will be tracked. Recognizing that the classic limiting nutrients nitrogen and phosphorus (P) are typically available in excess in these nutrient impacted systems prompts this study to focus specifically on how changing N form in the presence of adequate nutrient supplies alter phytoplankton community composition and physiology. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

por.por_cntn:
Research

 

            China’s marine and freshwaters are among the most nitrogen (N) polluted in the world. The rise in N pollution in China has been linked with severe water quality impairment, ranging from large cyanobacteria algae blooms, particularly those of Microcystis aeruginosa, reductions in oxygen resulting in fish kills, and increased frequency of toxic and nontoxic harmful algae blooms. Not only are N loads rising in China, but the relative N forms reaching aquatic ecosystems are changing (shift from NO3- to more NH4+), as a result of sewage effluent from expanding populations and the rise in N fertilizer use. This project investigated whether changes in phytoplankton community composition, including harmful algal blooms, were associated with changes in nitrogen loading. Understanding the relationship between N form and harmful algae blooms will help identify management practices that would mitigate algae species that are noxious to ecosystems and to human health.

            The freshwaters of West Lake in Hangzhou, China, are degraded by N pollution, and despite the implementation of management practices to improve water quality algae blooms continue to appear. Some of these blooms taint and discolor the water, and increase water purifications costs for treatment.  This project combined experimental and field approaches to determine how nitrogen form impacts water quality and phytoplankton community composition in West Lake. The phytoplankton community composition was characterized along a gradient of nutrient conditions in West Lake, and compared to the community composition following enrichment experiments with different N forms.  A gradient in nitrogen concentrations was observed across the lake, which supported different types of algae.  The addition of NH4+ to water samples resulted in a shift in community composition from diatoms to more cyanobacteria. This result lends support to the hypothesis that in environments enriched with N, and where NH4+ is increasing, phytoplankton community compositions will shift, with large diatoms giving way to small cyanobacteria and dinoflagellates. Much of the classic literature on cyanobacteria nutrient use has focused on the concept that cyanobacteria production is limited by N or phosphorus (P). This project recognizes that both N and P are typically available in excess in these nutrient enriched systems and provides us with a better understanding of how changing N form alters phytoplankton community composition. Although none of the blooms observed were thought to be toxic, the fact that West Lake is used for drinking water, irrigation, and attracts tourists worldwide makes this an important issue for management in this system.  Overall, assessing the impact of increasing NH4+ in enriched waters has significance for West Lake, as well as comparative systems across China and elsewhere where N loading is high.
